turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: We'll hear argument next in Number 98-1101, Rohn F. Drye v. United States.
Mr. Traylor.
You're the only lawyer to come by himself we've seen in a long time.
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, members of the Court, may it please the Court:
For our Socratic dialogue I am armed with a borrowed Gideon and the fruit.
This is... these aids go right to the jugular of this case, and the genesis of the case, which is Chapter 3 of Genesis.
What we have here is, when the serpent extended the fruit to the offeree, free will said that the offeree had a right to accept or reject the gift.
Assuming that that offeree was a tax delinquent, the Government's position is that their 6321 Federal tax lien attached at the moment that the serpent extended the fruit.
That is not...

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, of course, the IRS was not in Paradise.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: [Laughter]

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: I'm... that is where the case starts, is with the idea of free will, that people have a right to accept or reject a gift.
The Government don't believe that.
They believe that when you have the right to make that decision and grab the fruit, that their lien attached to that personal right of decision to elect.
I don't believe that that's the law of this Court, as announced by this Court.
I don't believe...

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Mr. Traylor, the Government is not relying on the Good Book, but it is relying on title 26 of the Internal Revenue Code and there the matter of disclaimer is dealt with in the estate and gift tax context, but it isn't... the permission for a disclaimer appears expressly in the estate and gift tax.
There is no such provision for the Tax Lien Act, so the Government is saying, Congress did not choose to provide for disclaimer in that context, so there is none.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: What Congress said was that for their tax lien to attach, the taxpayer must have property or rights to the property.
When Mrs. Drye died, at the instant of her death, the Government's position is that Mr. Drye acquired a right to property, or property in her estate.
That is not the law of the State of Arkansas, and it is not the law that this Court has pronounced.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But as I understood it, Mr. Traylor, at least the Eighth Circuit felt that way, that under Arkansas law your client acquired a property interest upon death, because he didn't remit it for a number of months afterwards.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: Well, he has 9 months within which to make that personal...

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Yes, well, who owned the real estate during the 9 months before the decision was made?
Who owned it, do you suppose?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: The law is very clear that the estate owned it.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: You don't think, in the case of real property, that the title went to the beneficiary...

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: Absolutely not.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: under Arkansas law?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: Absolutely not.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Let me ask you this.
Did Mr. Drye have a right to transfer whatever right he had to his mother's estate before he acquired it...

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: He would acquire...

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: under Arkansas law?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: acquire that right if, and only if, he accepted, took a bite of the apple.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: You don't think there's any way, under Arkansas law, that before all of this happened, even before his mother died, could he transfer whatever right he had to someone?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: Only if he took a bite of the apple.
Nothing vests until you accept the gift, the offer of the gift.
You... there has to be an act of an acceptance.
At that point, Mr. Drye would acquire an interest or a property in his mother's estate sufficient for the tax lien to attach.
That never happened.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Traylor, the district judge who, I'm sure, must have been an Arkansas practicing lawyer before he was appointed to the bench, found against you on this point, and the court of appeals, which certainly knows more about Arkansas law than we do, found against you, saying that there was a property interest under Arkansas law, so you have kind of a heavy burden to persuade us otherwise.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: Well, very simply, Judge Howard in the Eighth Circuit got it backwards.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: They don't realize it, though.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: [Laughter]

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: They will when this Court instructs them what the fact of the matter is, and the fact of the matter is that the Fifth... the Fifth Circuit and the Ninth Circuit on... I'm on all fours in near identical facts... found just the opposite, on very recent opinions.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But they didn't do it on the grounds that you had no property interest.
They did it on the grounds that the disclaimer relates back, isn't that right?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: I don't think, Your Honor.
I think that they found that the taxpayer in both States never acquired an interest sufficient for a tax lien to attach.
This is not really about the disclaimer and the relation back.
It's whether anything ever vested, a right in property, or property itself, that under Federal law is sufficient.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Let me ask you this.

If the administrator had announced that he was going to liquidate the estate and take the money and go to Las Vegas and have a good time, would you have had the right to do anything about that, your client have the right to do anything about it?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: Well, see, my client was the administrator...

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Would he have sat back and said, too bad, I have no property interest, or rights to property, so I guess the administrator can look forward to a good time?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: Had he disclaimed prior to that...

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: That's not my question.
He hadn't taken any action one way or the other.
The administrator is on the way to Las Vegas.
Can he do anything about it?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: What?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: He can accept... he can take a bite of the apple and go to State court and say, enjoin that administrator from going to Las Vegas.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: And he would say, when he got to court, would he not, I have a right to inherit that property if I want to, and therefore he can't go to Las Vegas with it?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: He's bitten the apple, and he's... the tax lien has attached.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Let's assume you are representing him, and he says, I'm not biting the apple, I am simply asserting a right to bite the apple, haven't bitten yet.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Can he stop?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: I believe that by... that that would be an act of acceptance by going to court and saying that I am protecting my interest.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: And he had a right to do that, I take it?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: I am acknowledging...

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: And he has a right to go into court and do that, doesn't he?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: He has a right to do that when he does it.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But not before?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: That is exactly right.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: He creates it himself?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: It's inchoate.
It's unvested.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: He creates the right himself?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: By an act of faith...

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: The law of the State has nothing to do with it?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: an act of free will.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Yes, but may I suggest the difference in your hypothetical.
It seems to me that if the offeree said to the offeror, I'm not sure what I want to do.
I'll let you know in 30 days.
During that 30 days, the offeror could have taken the apple back.
But in Arkansas the court would not have allowed the offeror to take it back for 30 days, because he has a 9-month period in which to make a decision.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: This Court... well, Congress has said that you have a reasonable period of time within... to make that election.
The State of Arkansas has said that you have a reasonable period of time to make that election.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Where did Congress say that?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: In their identical qualified disclaimer for gift and generation...

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Where they say, for purposes of this subchapter, being the estate and gift tax, so it's clear that they didn't say it with respect to tax liens.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: It's in the same book.
I would say...
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: It's not in the same subchapter.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: A different subchapter.

I'm not a tax expert, but I can tell you for sure that the model probate code of which Arkansas, Texas, Arizona, North Dakota, and by my count 30 other States have said that you have 9 months as a reasonable... and it tracks the Federal system.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Mr. Traylor, what about stock options?
Are they taxable as property?
I mean, I have an option to buy stock in a company that I've worked for for a number of years.
I don't have to exercise the option.
I can just let it lapse.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: If you are a tax delinquent, a 6321 Federal tax lien has attached to your rights in those stock options, and...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I thought so.
Now, how does that... but how does that square with your case?
I have free will.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: Well, because you...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I don't have to bite the apple.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: No.
You have...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I can let the stock option just lapse.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: You have a vested interest.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Oh, I don't have a vested interest.
I have an ability...

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: Because...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: to assert an interest by agreeing to exercise the option, but I don't have to agree to exercise it.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: Assuming the options are not underwater, then that stock option is property or rights to property for 6321 because it's transferable and has pecuniary value.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Transferable?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: You could transfer the option to another.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: No.
This is a nonassignable option.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: The Government says transferability, and I really don't care about... but it has pecuniary value.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It has pecuniary value only... so does your client's, only if exercised.
I have a nontransferable option to buy this stock.
The employee can only exercise it personally.
He can't assign it to anybody else.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: I believe the Government could come and seize that option and step in...

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: I'm sure it can.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: And step into your shoes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And I don't understand why it can't come and seize your client's interest in the estate.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: Because nothing had ever vested.
It was a personal right of decision that was without pecuniary value.
It was nontransferable.
It's not recognized at law or in equity in Arkansas.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: How does that differ from the stock... does my stock option have any pecuniary value, if I cannot assign it to anybody?
I couldn't sell it to anyone.
I can't get a bank loan on it.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: The Government can step into your shoes and exercise...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Of course.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: Can the Government step in...

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Why?

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Because it's property.
So why can't the Government step into your client's shoes...

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: Because...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: and exercise it because it's property?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: Because the right of election is not property.
It has no value.
My client can't take a nickel for his right of decision.
By definition, a disclaimer has to be without consideration, otherwise the Government would have sued us under the Federal Debt Collection Procedures Act of 1990, the fraudulent transfer.

In fact, that is what Judge Howard has called me, and Judge Brantley, the chancellor and probate judge who adjudicated the disposition of this interesting question, called us both a... fraudulent transferors.
This thing is... Mr. Drye's disclaimer, his personal right of election, it's one of two things.
It was either a lawful act or a fraudulent transfer.
It's either a transfer, or it's not.
I suggest it...

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: I don't understand this very basic thing.
It seems to me that if I have a right to receive the entire estate, a right to receive it if I want it, then I have something of large value, and it's up to me whether I want to realize on it.
But to say that it's valueless until he takes a bite of it, I mean, he's... he can realize on it if he wants to.
He's solely in control.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: Your Honor, it's been the common law of England and this country, codified by statute in Arkansas, until you take that bite of the apple, you do not have a vested interest in her estate.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: That's, you say is the Arkansas law.
There are States, are there not, where a person in the position of Mr. Drye would be deemed to have had the property and then given it up.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: Absolutely.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: And then... so if we took your view of it, it would depend which State you come from whether the tax lien would attach.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: That is correct, and one of the beauties of our Federal system that different States define their interest a little bit different.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Suppose...
Has the supreme court of Arkansas ever held that the sort of expectancy that your client had before he disclaimed was transferable, or saleable, or that it was not transferable or saleable?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: Has never interpreted our probate code since the model act was adopted in '84.
To answer your question, sure.
I mean, if Mr....

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: No, I'm asking you a specific question about the holdings of the supreme court of Arkansas.
Has the supreme court of Arkansas ever held that the sort of interest your client had before he disclaimed was or was not transferable or saleable?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: The court would say that it is a transferable interest, and once you have transferred it, you've bitten the apple, your right to...

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: No, I mean before you disclaimed.
During the period before you disclaimed, has the supreme court of Arkansas ever said whether or not that interest was transferable or saleable?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: I'm doing my best, Your Honor.
It's... that is an act of the bite of the apple, and...

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: I'm not... don't tell me about the bite of the apple any more.

Just tell me what the supreme court of Arkansas has done, or if it hasn't done anything... I mean, this seems the key to your whole case, and if there's a case out there that is... shows the Eighth Circuit and the district court were wrong, you should surely have it.
What is that case?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: The Fifth and Ninth Circuit decisions.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: What about the Rutherford case of the State of Arkansas, which as I understand it says that one can agree to convey an expectancy in an estate?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: You can.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: All right, so why doesn't that indicate that a transfer of an expectancy is transferable, it's property, it has value?
That's what I get from the Rutherford case, and it seems to me that's the case we ought to talk about.
Now, maybe you have ways to distinguish it.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: Because it begs the question.
The interest has already vested.
The act of assignment of the...

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: An expectancy is not vested.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: It is once you assign it.
You can no longer disclaim.
It would be a bar to disclaimer.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, I guess after you accept the devise, and while the estate is still in administration, what you have might be called an expectancy.
I'm not sure I'm that interested in what the supreme court of Arkansas has to say.

To come back to my stock option example, suppose the State of Delaware, in order to make itself even more attractive to corporations, passes a law that says, henceforward stock options in the stock of Delaware corporations are not property...

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: This Court...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: would the Federal Government still be able to tax those stock options?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: This Court answered that question very clearly in the National Bank of Commerce case, which I believe to be the leading case on the question, and States can't define what is or is not property.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: For purposes of the Federal tax law.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: So...
You say States can't define what is or is not property for purposes of Federal tax law?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: They cannot.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: I thought our cases held just the opposite, that the statute says if you have property the Government can get it, but whether or not you have property is up to State law.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: You look at the interest under State law, and then under National Bank of Commerce you then look to see if that interest is property or rights to property, and the definition primarily is, does it have pecuniary value.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: The State law defines your rights, but whether that bundle of rights, whatever it is, rises to the level of being property under the Internal Revenue Code is a matter of Federal law.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: Precisely, because of your Delaware example.
You can't let States define what has incumbered the tax man.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Then it's irrelevant for our purposes that as a matter of Arkansas law the decision to disclaim relates back to the date of death, and that therefore the... as a matter of Arkansas law he never had any property.
That's irrelevant, is that right?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: My best answer is, you look in depth at State law to ascertain what is the nature of the interest or right under State law, and if you'll do that in this example, you will find that Mr. Drye never acquired an interest sufficient to be defined under Federal law as property, or rights to property.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Mr. Traylor, I'm just curious about why the taxpayer, Mr. Drye being in this situation, he didn't have his mother write a will leaving the estate to the daughter.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: We had an appointment with her on the day of her death to execute a will.
That really affected... I mean, that's why my name is in the caption.

I mean, that was what was to happen, and it's just one of those things in life that, in fact, Mr. Drye did not want to go talk to his mamma and tell her... Mr. Drye was 70, his mamma was almost 92, I believe, at the time.
He didn't want to go tell his mother, sign this piece of paper so that we don't have to be up here today.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: If he had done that, what if you... if it's not an intestate disposition, but there is a will, and you are one of the beneficiaries of the will, all right, and what if you say, I don't want this property.
You simply decline the bequest.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: That has been the common law of England and this country for...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You can do it?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: hundreds of years.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You can do it?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: Absolutely.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And are you... is that considered... your interest in that bequest considered property for purposes of the Federal tax law?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: The Fifth and Ninth Circuit said it wasn't.
The only circuit that has said it is is the Eighth Circuit.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: No, I'm talking... yes.
I'm not talking about intestate disposition.
I'm talking about a bequest, and...

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: The Fifth and Ninth Circuit were both... were both bequests.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Do you think the two should be the same?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: Absolutely, and that was the purpose that the commissioners on uniform State laws got together and said, look, there isn't any reason... for the last 500 years we have let people have the freedom to decline gifts in... bequests, not make a person an owner against their consent, but if it's an inheritance you will take, whether you will or not.
That was the law in England and the United States for a long time.
The commissioner got together and said, look, there isn't any reason for that, particularly as you look at the Federal tax consequences.
One is a transfer, one is not.

They got together back in the mid-sixties, they removed the common law anomaly of... feudalism is where that distinction arose hundreds and hundreds of years ago, and the State of Arkansas has adopted it, Texas, Arizona, North Dakota, and by my count 30 other jurisdictions.
They have removed the distinction between the two of them.
This case is... the Fifth Circuit decision is right on point, and it's the best analysis that I have seen of it, and the recent Ninth Circuit decision.
Both of them to me are very thoughtful decisions, and I understand that this is not a very palatable result that has resulted.
Mr. Drye didn't pay his taxes.
The Government needs the taxes, and through this sleight of hand... but these people across the street over...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: The Government doesn't really need the tax.
They had a surplus, I think.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: [Laughter]

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: Well, the people across the street in Congress can very easily change it.
In their wisdom, they have chosen not to make a disclaimer a fraudulent conveyance.

In fact, in the State of Arkansas Mr. Drye would not have had this ability to have disclaimed up until about the mid-eighties, because at that time the law was an insolvent beneficiary could not disclaim.
That bar was removed, oh, in the mid eighties.
Chief Justice, if I might, if there's no other present questions, could I reserve the balance of my time?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Yes, you may.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Jones, we'll hear from you.

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
I want...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Mr. Jones, you don't have a stick that you're going to turn into a snake or anything like that, do you?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: [Laughter]

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: I knew this day was going to come.
I just was hoping it wouldn't be today.
[Laughter]
I wanted to say 5 seconds' worth about the apple, and then talk about the law.
This case does not involve an offer of a gift.
This case... an offeree doesn't have any legal rights in the proposed gift.
He can't enforce the offer.
This case involves an intestate succession to which petitioner is the sole heir, had lawfully and legally enforceable rights in Arkansas.
With that background, I'd like to now talk about what the legal issue is.
The legal issue is, what's the scope of the Federal tax lien?

Section 6321 of the Internal Revenue Code creates a Federal lien in all property and rights to property of any delinquent taxpayer, and in a long series of cases, beginning with the Glass City Bank case in 1945, the Court has plainly set out the way that we're supposed to answer these questions.

First, you look to State law to see what the nature of the interest that the taxpayer has is, and then secondly, Federal law governs the determination of whether that interest is property or rights to property under the Federal lien.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Would you treat testate and intestate the same?

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: Almost certainly the answer would be the same, and certainly the method of answering the question is the same.
The method is, did the taxpayer have a valuable, legally protected right to receive the property.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: If you treat testate the same, then what about the Government's attaching a tax lien to a gift that I've offered?
I haven't died yet, but I've offered my son a particular gift.

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: Your son would have no legally protected right, no enforceable right to make you transfer that property to him.
That's why I wanted to make that point at the beginning.
This case does not involve that situation.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: What if State law is that, like an offer, the offer of a gift remains open until it's accepted?

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: I'm not sure what that would mean, but if I understand it correctly, you're saying that...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It means, all he has to say is, I accept, and the property...

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: Oh, he has a legally enforceable right under State law to accept.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: To accept the gift?

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: That is a valuable interest, a valuable, legally protected right that this Court has explained in many cases.
It falls within the Federal concept of what's property for purposes of the tax lien.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Supposing that you have some State court cases on the subject that don't speak directly to the issue in question.
What is the test?
What do you look for in State law to see whether the person has a legally protected interest?

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: Well, one clear example is the situation we have here, where it's the sort of interest that can be transferred, that the State will allow you to transfer the interest.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Transferability is sufficient, then?

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: That would certainly be sufficient to indicate that it was a legally protected right.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But you don't think it's necessary?

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: No, sir, not at all.
I think there are lots of legally protected rights that involve property interests that you can't transfer, like a spendthrift trust.
Indeed, that's where this money ended up in this case.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: It's true that this is a little unusual in that here you have the Arkansas statute, which says for all purposes, once it's disclaimed, it disappears.
It's not like a stock option in that sense, which I guess for a lot of purposes of State law, even after the expiration date, State law might have had some bite.
I mean, there are all kinds of State laws.
So I looked up the bankruptcy law to see how Federal law treats it.
It seems to me that under the bankruptcy provisions this would not count as an interest in property for purposes of a fraudulent transfer.
I can check it again, but I don't know if you've looked into that.

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: I'm not prepared to address that question.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Well, if it turns out that for bankruptcy purposes this isn't treated as an interest, I mean, I... why... you haven't thought about it, so I... you're not...

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: Well, I... even without thinking about it in much depth at all, I mean, what we're dealing with is not only section 6321 of the Internal Revenue Code, but a fairly large body of precedent of this Court under that statute, and...

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Well...
On the precedent, I couldn't find any.
That is to say, the reason is, statutorily this doesn't count as a property right for tax purposes, because they have all these statutes, you know, that let you disclaim.
Then I couldn't find something other than that.
Now, tell me, what is... what do you...

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: I'm not even sure what you're referring to, these statutes that let you dis...

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: You have a gift tax, you have an estate tax...

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: Only for those purposes.
The Internal... what... and, of course, that's an entirely different subject.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: The reason that the disclaimers are allowed if they're made within this window under... for purposes of the gift and estate tax, is to avoid imposing a double tax on what's essentially a single flow-through.

But the reason that the Federal tax lien reaches this property is because the taxpayer had that legally enforceable right to decide what he wanted to do with it, which was a valuable right, and the fairness interest that I think Congress is concerned about under the Tax Lien Act is the fairness of requiring taxpayers B, C, D, and E, to pay more than their fair share to make up for the fact that taxpayer A hasn't paid his taxes.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: You were going to tell me some Federal precedent.

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: Yes.

Well, to me the case that really tells us how to decide this question is the National Bank of Commerce case, where the Court said that in view of the comprehensive nature of the statutory language that Congress employed, that this lien reaches every valuable right, every species of right or interest that a taxpayer might invest in...

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Every specie of right or interest, so in fact you would say this reaches even a similar situation under a will where the testator isn't dead yet?

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: Well, I... the testator can revoke his will.
We're talking...

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Exactly, so...

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: But what we're talking about is something that is a right that the taxpayer has, and under Arkansas law, for example, the taxpayer could assign his expectancy in such an estate, and so I suppose we could take the position, which we don't need to reach in this case.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, but the devisee has no action against the testator to...

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: Of course not.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: if the testator revokes.

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: Right, so I mean, it would be very hard to figure out what would be the value that the lien would attach to.

But what I want to... the point I keep heading toward is that in National Bank of Commerce what the Court said was that nothing more than common sense is required to conclude that a right to receive property is itself a interest in property that the lien attaches to, and that is precisely the nature of the interest that the taxpayer in this case has.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: What is the legal error of the Fifth Circuit right?

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: The Fifth Circuit in Leggett was wrong exactly for the reasons I've just described.

In Leggett, the Court said that the Federal lien doesn't attach to this right to receive property because under State law that is just a personal privilege, and it's not a property interest for purposes of State law.

And that's flatly inconsistent with the two fundamental holdings of the Court in National Bank of Commerce, the first of which is that Federal law, not State law, governs in deciding what's property under the tax lien and, secondly, that the right to receive property is property under the tax lien.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: So you look to State law to find the nature of the interest, and you look to the Federal law to see if it's property?

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: That's exactly what the Court held in National Bank of Commerce.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, that's a little bit more intricate, more intricate than one needs, perhaps.

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: Well, these intricacies rarely arise, but when they arise, that's how they're to be resolved.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What was the interest under Texas law?
Was it Texas the Fifth Circuit was deciding?

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: Yes.

It was... I... it was interest under a will, but the principles of property that govern the disposition of that interest are the same, whether it's intestate or testate and, indeed, as we pointed out in our brief, the State court... I mean, I'm sorry, the Fifth Circuit in Leggett seems to us to have erred in its description of how State law operates, to say all they had was a right of decision.
They had a lot more than a right to decision.
As the Eighth Circuit pointed out in this case, under the similar provisions of Arkansas...

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Excuse me, a right of rescission or decision?

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: Decision is what the Fifth Circuit called it.
Under the State law they have an absolute right to receive the property without doing anything.
They don't have to make a decision, any more than I have to make a decision to withdraw money out of my bank account.
It's still my property.
If I withdraw it...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: He has a property right, but does he have a property right in the assets of the estate?
Let's...

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, I...

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: There's a right to receive it.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Suppose I make you a contractual offer that is open for 90 days, and under most States' laws nowadays, if I say it's open for 90 days, you can count on that.
That is worth something.
It's a beneficial contract to you.

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: If it's an irrevocable offer for 90 days.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It's an irrevocable offer for 90 days.

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: Then you have a right to accept it.
It's a valuable right.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You have a right to accept it.

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: It's subject to Federal lien.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Right, now what would you slam your lien on, my... the property that I have... that's the subject of the contract?

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: What I would... the lien would be... I would have the... I would... it depends at what stage we're at.
If I... if I try to...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: The 90 days have gone by.

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: If I try to...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: The 90 days have now gone by, the guy never exercised the...

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: Oh, the offer wasn't accepted?

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It wasn't accepted.

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: Has it expired?

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It's expired.

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: Well then, there's nothing left for us to attach to.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, he had a power to accept it.
He just didn't.
Just as in this case he had a power to accept it, but he didn't.

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: No, he doesn't have a power to accept it.
He has the right to accept it.
It's not a power, it's a right.
He can...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Okay, I'll call it a right in the other case, too, then.

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: He can transfer...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: They're both the same.

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: This really is a fundamentally different concept.
He can transfer this right away.
He can, quote, disclaim it, which the Court said in the... in the Irvine case was an indirect transfer of it.
He can get rid of it.
But as this Court's held in Best, and Phelps...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: What do you mean, transfer it?
Can he give it to somebody else to accept it?

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: Who?
We're talking about this taxpayer?

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: Yes.
He could transfer his right to receive the property by an assignment under State law.

Indeed, you don't have to look further than the State's disclaimer provisions to see that an assignment... that this interest can be assigned, because once you've assigned it, you can then no longer disclaim it.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, I suppose the same in the contract case.
I could say, you know, if I accept this contract, I assign to you my rights under it.

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: And the Federal...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You can't accept it for me, but if I do accept it, you'll have my rights under it.

I see no difference in the two cases, and I don't... in other words, I acknowledge that it's property, but is the property the assets of the estate, or is it, rather, this right to accept it, which is intangible, and which I don't know how you can...

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: The easiest way to answer it is by reference to the Court's decision in the Phelps case.

The Federal lien attaches to the property and to... however it is transferred, and to anything substituted for it, and because of that, the lien exists at all phases of this... I'm sorry, at all phases of this...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well...

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: factual pattern.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But it seems to me that's too fast to say the lien attaches to the property.
I agree, but what is the property?
It is not the assets of the estate.
It is his right to obtain those assets.

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: It's his right to receive them initially.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: And then when he transfers that right the lien follows that along to whoever obtained that right.

In this case, it was his daughter, and then it attached to the assets themselves when she received them, and then it continued to attach to the assets as they were transferred to the trust, and because it continued to exist in these properties, the properties were lawfully seized for collection of taxes.
That's the fact pattern.

There was one other opinion of the court of appeals that I do need to discuss, the Mapes decision in the Ninth Circuit, which reached a similarly incorrect as Leggett, but did it by a different route.

What the Court held in the Mapes case was that the Federal lien doesn't attach to the taxpayer's right to receive the estate, because once the taxpayer renounces the interest, it's said to be renounced for all purposes under State law, and the Court said, therefore the taxpayer should be treated as if he never owned an interest in the property.

The clear error in that decision is, the court didn't cite any of this Court's decisions and, in particular, didn't cite the Mitchell case, where this Court held that a retroactive renunciation of a property interest... and I'm quoting... should not be misinterpreted as an indication that the taxpayer never owned an interest in the property.
This Court has consistently held that you look to the realizable economic value of the taxpayer's rights, and you don't look to the State law fictions of retroactive renunciations and disclaimers.
As the Court held in the Irvine case, Federal tax law is not struck blind by the State's legal fiction of a retroactive disclaimer.
The lien attached to the rights at the time that it arose, and subsequent dispositions of that, of the interest could not destroy the Federal lien.
Unless the Court has further questions...

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I do, actually.

I might... I have one, and you're probably not going to have an answer, because we haven't looked it up, and I haven't, either, but as I was looking at the bankruptcy law, the reason that I was concerned is the following.
Imagine the taxpayer in this case had done just what he did, but he did it 30 days before going bankrupt.

What... if I'm right about the bankruptcy law, the interpretation would mean, if we got yours, is that his creditors, who were private, couldn't get at the money, and the reason is, it would not be a, quote, interest in property, but the Government, as taxpayer, would be able to get at the money, and the reason would be because it is, quote, a right to property.

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: Well...

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Now, that seemed, you know, a little odd.

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: That is possible.

I'm not in a position to say yea or nay, but I can say it's a very common situation that the Federal tax lien applies in a situation where private creditors have no opportunity to... I mean, that's what the Best case was precisely about.
And the courts held that it doesn't matter whether under other law, State law in that case, whether you have a... whether other creditors could seize it.
This is a question of Federal law under section 6321, and under the Federal law, if the Federal law provides a lien, that's the answer to the question.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And...
Mr. Jones, can I pursue... you said that the lien attaches to his right to get the property.
If he exercises that right, it attaches to the property which is the product.
But if he doesn't exercise the option, and somebody else gets the property, that... I don't see it as being the product of his option any more.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: How can you...

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: I don't... what do you mean by doesn't exercise the option that... this taxpayer doesn't have to do anything to get the property.
It's his automatically.
That's the point I was trying to make earlier.
He can transfer his right, but if he doesn't do anything, if he doesn't write a disclaimer, he doesn't make an assignment, that property comes to him.
Why?
Because he already has a vested right to receive that property under State law.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, indeed, this was real property, I take it...

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: Some of it.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: and I thought the title went to Mr. Drye immediately, subject to this State law right to disclaim later, but I thought he held the title immediately.
Is that right, or wrong?

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: That's the way the court of appeals described it, and that's my understanding of Arkansas law as well.
The court of appeals, I...

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But again, that's not necessary to your position, as I understand your position.

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: It would be different, though, would it not, if State law provided that a beneficiary, an intestate... an heir has to file a piece of paper in court identifying himself or herself and saying affirmatively, I want the money?

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: It would only be different if the right were not...

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: He would have no right to the money unless he filed that piece of paper?

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: Well, if they had the right to the money, if they had a legally protected right to...

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But he had to take an affirmative step to do it?

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: That goes back to the colloquy I had with Justice Scalia.
If he has a legally protected right that is vested in him to receive this money...

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: As a matter of State law, though, the nature of the interest... the nature of the interest is, he has nothing, unless he files that piece of paper.

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: Well, you... that's an interesting point.
I really haven't thought about that.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: It's different.

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: If he had to take a specific act, and he doesn't take the act, that would be a harder problem, and I'm not sure how we come out.
This case is not like that.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: You say the...

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: I want to point out, the Eighth Circuit said that he doesn't have to do anything.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: No, I understand.

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: They made that point.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I understand that.
But the Commerce case was a bank account.
I mean, he clearly owned the money.
It's just a question of how much, between the joint account, isn't that right, because he had... you relied there on the fact he had a right to withdraw the money.

turn.speaker: kent_l_jones
turn.label: Mr. Kent L. Jones
turn.text: He had a right to receive the money, which is... I'm using the words of the Court in the National Bank of Commerce case, and they pointed out that it didn't matter whether that was a right that the State law would call a property right.
It didn't matter that he couldn't get the money until some day in the future.
What mattered was that at the time the lien attached, he had a vested right to get that money at some point.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Jones.
Mr. Traylor, you have 5 minutes remaining.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: Thank you, Your Honor.
The Government has taken all of my cases.

They're... Mitchell, down in Louisiana, those delinquent taxpayers, they had a present right, and then they tried to disclaim it, and the Court said, look, an act of God cannot remove a Federal tax lien once it's attached, and I agree with that.
The question... the problem here is, it never attached.
Irvine, the Court recently has stated that the... this idea of acceptance or rejection of estates can be based on a gift theory.
That is what we're talking... we're not talking about a mechanism to defeat creditors.
We're talking about transfer and succession of estates.
Best, that's my case.
The delinquent taxpayer at any time could go get the cash value of his life insurance policies.
The fact that he later executed a disclaimer, you can't... a State disclaimer can't extinguish a Federal tax lien once it attached.
The only people who can do that are the people across the street.
Two interesting things, the Government says that, in his opening statement that... I... that this idea of the bite of the apple, look at page 22 of their brief.
It says in the second full paragraph, an offer which can be accepted or rejected is itself an interest in property.
Here's an offer you can accept or reject.
The Government lien has attached.
I submit to you that that ain't the law of the country.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, it's... the Government's changed his position a little bit.
I... and says that if the offer is framed in such a way that the property is yours unless you affirmatively reject, you have property on which the lien...

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: The act of doing nothing is an affirmative act that cooks your goose.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: The act of doing nothing is an affirmative act?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: Exactly.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Let me contemplate that for a minute.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: [Laughter]

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: Over the passage of time, and I would like to...

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: The statute doesn't say interest, it says right.
It says you have a right to property, and if you do nothing, and you get the property, and legally you're entitled to it, how don't you have a right to property?
It didn't say interest.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: You have a right to accept or reject, but more importantly, I would like to go to your bankruptcy question.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Well, I just distinguished it away, because I said it uses interest and not right.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: On the...

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: You go ahead and defend it.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: On the bankruptcy question, whether a trustee has a right to avoid a disclaimer made within, oh, I guess it would be 4 months, the Government ought to read note 17 of its own brief, where they represent that the trustee does have such a right.
I submit to you that they do not read that section of the Bankruptcy Code properly.
The only thing that generally the bankruptcy trustee can avoid are transfers.
Disclaimers, by definition, cannot be a transfer, because you cannot accept any consideration for it.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Mr. Traylor, do I take it from what you've just said, cannot be a transfer, that the estate gift tax provision for disclaimer, that was unnecessary, that the provision for it, for purposes of that subchapter, Congress didn't need to do that?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: Congress had to do it, because it treated people differently.
If you received under a will, you were not taxed.
If you received it by an inheritance, you will take it whether you will or not.
You can transfer it the next day, but you're going to be taxed.
And people raised Cain and said, what's the difference?
Congress said there is no difference, so we're going to treat both of you the same.
And then the State law commissioners got on the same bandwagon and...

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Traylor.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_traylor
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Traylor
turn.text: Thank you, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: The case is submitted.
